abstract.p: Letter from Rodney W Nichols, New York Academy of Sciences president, says fusing academic excellence and entrepreneurial verve can accelerate economic development in New York region (Aug 2 article)

block.p: Universities in New York certainly need to be more aggressive in licensing and selling their intellectual property, following the successes of Columbia University (news article, Aug. 2). Yet there is a larger strategic goal for our region as a whole, and it's one that Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio need to emphasize. The region should exploit its scientific and technological assets far more effectively than it does in order to achieve real economic growth.

Universities in New York certainly need to be more aggressive in licensing and selling their intellectual property, following the successes of Columbia University (news article, Aug. 2). Yet there is a larger strategic goal for our region as a whole, and it's one that Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio need to emphasize. The region should exploit its scientific and technological assets far more effectively than it does in order to achieve real economic growth.

New York, New Jersey and Connecticut can be competitive in national and global markets only when their universities see themselves as part of the regional economy. Evidence from around the world shows that academic excellence and entrepreneurial verve must be fused to accelerate economic development. RODNEY W. NICHOLS President New York Academy of Sciences New York, Aug. 3, 2000
